Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Algorithm Design and Analysis for Students in Undergraduate Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding renews a highly successful CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Houston. The theme of this site is algorithm design and analysis focusing on real-time, parallel, data-intensive problems in large-scale heterogeneous, and highly distributed modern computing environments. Students will receive ten-week intensive training in specific research fields as well as basic research skills including literature review, algorithm design and implementation, experiment setup, data analysis, technical writing and presentation. The research projects are interdisciplinary and an emphasis will be placed on teamwork and collaboration. Local researchers from the Texas Medical Center, NASA Johnson Space Center, and oil industry will helps provide mentoring to the students.

This site will introduce 30 undergraduate students (over three years) to computing research, with a goal of directing more U.S. undergraduates into graduate computing programs. The host institution is both a Hispanic Serving Institution as well as a Minority Serving Institution, so this project will help attract minority students into STEM programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the four years supported by this grant, 28 highly selected students from all across the US came to UHD and undertook 10 summer weeks of intensive learning and research endeavors. Students worked closely with their faculty mentors to master vital research skills including research methodology, communication, team work, and domain exploration. Numerous workshops, symposiums, field trips were organized. The REU students produced many high quality, peer-reviewed papers. Some recent publications are listed here (REU student authors’ names underlined):

Beatrice M. Cerda, Ester Martinez-Belmares, and Shengli Yuan, “Detection and Protection against Black Hole Attacks in Wired Networks,” 28th HENAAC Conference. Anaheim, CA. October, 2016,  (First place poster award)

Joseph Flinn, Hen Su Choi-Ortiz, and Shengli Yuan, “A Secure Routing Scheme for Networks with Unknown or Dynamic Topology using A-star Algorithm,” Proceedings, 15th International Conference on Security and Management (SAM’16), in conjunction with 2016 World Congress in Computer Science, Computer Engineering, & Applied Computing.  Las Vegas, NV. July, 2016.

Sishir Subedi, Yuezhe Li, Christopher Early, Alexander Chan, Jonathan Garza, Gregor Schreiber, Yuchou Chang, Hong Lin, "A System for the Analysis of EEG Data and Brain State Modeling," Quoc NamTran and Hamid R. Arabnia (eds.), Emerging Trends in Computational Biology, Bioinformatics, and Systems Biology Systems & Applications, Elsevier/MK. March, 2016

Christopher Early, Alexander Chan, Jonathan Garza, Gregor Schreiber, and Hong Lin, “A Web-Based System for Analyzing Electrical Impulses in Human Brain,” 7th International Multi-Conference on Complexity, Informatics and Cybernetics (IMCIC 2016), Orlando, Florida, March, 2016.

Christopher Early, Alexander Chan, Sishir Subedi, Yuezhe Li, and Hong Lin,"Analysis of Machine Learning Algorithms on EEG Data for Brain State Intelligence," 2015 Workshop on Health Informatics and Data Science (HIDS), IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics & Biomedicine,
Washington DC. November 2015

Joseph Flinn, Hen Su Choi-Ortiz, and Shengli Yuan, “A Secure Routing Scheme in Unknown Networks Using A-star Algorithm” (Poster) Computing Alliance of Hispanic Serving Institutions (CAHSI) Summit 2015. San Juan, Puerto Rico, September, 2015.

Christopher Early, Alexander Chan, “Systematic Analysis and Classification of EEG Data using Machine Learning Algorithms” (Poster), Computing Alliance of Hispanic Serving Institutions (CAHSI) Summit 2015. San Juan, Puerto Rico, September, 2015.

Alexander Turner, Daniel Pareja and Dvijesh Shastri, “Detecting Drowsy Driving”, (Poster), Computing Alliance of Hispanic Serving Institutions (CAHSI) Summit 2015. San Juan, Puerto Rico, September, 2015.

Sishir Subedi, Jonathan Garza, Minghao Yang, Yunwei Cui, Hong Lin, “Dynamic Modeling of EEG Data for Brain State Intelligence”, The 9th China Summer Workshop on Information Management (CSWIM 2015), Hefei, China, June, 2015.

Mario Pagan, Audrey Hession, Shengli Yuan, “A Security-Enhanced Routing Algorithm with Path Randomization,” IEEE International Conference on Computing, Networking and Communications (ICNC 2015). Anaheim, California, February, 2015

Khanh Le, "Parallel Brain Waves Analysis and Brain States Modeling," REU  Symposium, Arlington, VA, October, 2014.

Khanh Le, “Parallel Brainwave Analysis and Brain State Modelling” (Poster presentation), the 5th Annual Technical Posters Competition, the 26th Annual HENAAC Conference, New Orleans, Louisiana, October, 2014.

Among the 28 REU participants, 18 have successfully completed undergraduate school. Among them, 8 were either accepted by a graduate school, or already enrolled in graduate school, including 6 in Ph.D. program in Computer Science. The other 10 are working in research and development in computer and IT industries. Among the REU students who are still in college, many are planning to apply or already applied for graduate schools.

11 CS courses at UHD benefited from the REU program through new learning modules and new projects created from the summer research programs, which positively impacted all students in our CS program.

The University of Houston-Downtown is recognized as a Hispanic Serving Institution as well as a Minority Serving Institution. This REU program together with other Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) programs offered at UHD have helped a large number of minority and women students to become more familiar with and more interested in STEM. The 28 participants came all across the US, and 15 of them were African/Hispanic/Women students. In our survey, all participants responded significant benefits from the intensive summer research experience, and brighter careers opportunities that followed. In addition, many students from the home institutions of the REU participants also became more attracted and interested in STEM after the participants shared their excitements and positive experiences. We can confidently conclude that the REU program at UHD has accomplished it objective to bring more students to pursue graduate degrees and research careers in both academia and industry, and help to relieve the urgent shortage of STEM professionals in this country.
